sub_title: Assistant Professor of Energy Informatics at Wageningen University | IEEE Senior Member
summary: I work as a Assistant Professor (UD1, with tenure-track) at the Information Technology group (INF), Wageningen University. My research is focused on Smart Energy Systems and Energy Informatics.  I am passionate about sustainable energy transition and believe in the key role digitalization plays in enabling that. From 2012 to 2016, I did my PhD (Cum-Laude) at the Statistical Analysis of Networks and Systems (SANS) research group, Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya (UPC, BarcelonaTech) in Spain. From 2016 to 2020, I was a postdoc at the Energy & Resources group, Copernicus Institute of Sustainable Development, Utrecht University, The Netherlands. This gave me a unique experience in combining my background in computer engineering with power network and energy systems, and creating new research contributions, with a large focus on the end-user side. I have worked on several Dutch and European research projects in the area of smart grids, including smart energy systems design, local energy communities and electricity markets, solar energy forecasting and smart integration of distributed energy resources, such as batteries and electric cars, all with an emphasis on using ICT platforms, modeling, optimization, and artificial intelligence.

education.field_of_study: Group of Statistical Analysis of Networks and Systems (SANS)

awards.title: Nominee Excellent Education Prize 2023
awards.description:
The course I coordinate and teach “Programming in Python” was one of the 3 large course nominees for the WUR Excellent Education Prize 2023.
This is a recognition of the continuous efforts we as a course team dedicated for re-designing and updating this course and an acknowledgement, by our students, peer colleagues and WUR education management, of the value of programming for education in all domains.
In this course we educate +500 students per academic year over 3 periods and we are very proud our students learn programming in less than 8 weeks and use it later in follow-up courses, in their thesis or even for improving their job hunting opportunity. Coordinating a large course, to me, does not only mean dealing with a large number of students but also a collective working environment with inspiring teachers, student assistants and supporting staff.

awards.title: Best Paper Award, International Conference on Smart Energy Systems and Technologies, 2020
awards.description: Our paper “The Impact of Transitioning to Shared Electric Vehicles on Grid Congestion and Management” received the best paper award in the 3rd IEEE international conference on Smart Energy Systems and Technologies (SEST 2020). The topic of paper is on shared electric vehicles (EVs) data analytics and flexibility assessment. Link to the paper: https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/9203241
awards.issuer: International Conference on Smart Energy Systems and Technologies (SEST) 2020

projects.title: HighLO
projects.description:
Project HighLO (High Energy Physics Tools in Limit Order Book Analysis) uses advanced data analytics from particle physics and artificial intelligence to better understand trading behavior in commodity and financial markets.  The project is a collaboration between Wageningen University & Research (WUR), the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) and The Commodity Risk Management Expertise Center (CORMEC).

https://www.highlo.org/

contributors.headline: Assistant Professor of Energy Informatics at Wageningen University | IEEE Senior Member

projects.title: Energy Intranets (NEAT)
projects.description:
Goal: Renewable energy from sources such as the sun and wind contributes to a sustainable world. Technology cannot compensate entirely for the high variability of these mostly decentralized energy generation systems, so it’s becoming increasingly difficult to balance the power grid. Based on a specific requirement by the power generation industry, this project will explore the potential of computational intelligence and big data analytics to better predict and utilize the flexibility of renewable supply and demand.

Participating institutions and companies: CWI, Delft University of Technology, Utrecht University, University of Amsterdam, SURFSara (IT facility for Dutch education and research), Sympower (demand response aggregator).

Funding agency: Dutch Research Council (NWO), Energy System Integration Call

contributors.headline: Assistant Professor of Energy Informatics at Wageningen University | IEEE Senior Member
Full Professor Integration of Photovoltaic Solar Energy at Utrecht University

projects.title: Smart Solar Charging
projects.description: A sustainable energy system at district level. Locally produced solar energy is stored in (pool) Electric Vehicles (EV). This energy can be released to the district at a later time, via a smart charging station. The experiences in  the Lombok neighborhood in Utrecht, the Netherlands, will be further developed over five years in five linked pilot areas in the Utrecht region. This will result in marketable product-service combinations for various types of areas. All areas combine the production of renewable energy with Vehicle to Grid (V2G) charging points and car sharing systems. Each pilot area has its own user profile, type of customer and specific market.

projects.title: B-DER: A Blockchain-based platform for P2P energy transactions between Distributed Energy Resources
projects.description:
The energy production landscape is being reshaped by distributed energy resources (DER), such as solar PV panels, electric vehicles, battery energy storage and charging stations. The rapid deployment of these DER calls for novel management schemes that can exploit the maximum economic and environmental potential of these resources, empower their end-users in a collaborative manner and at the same time guarantee grid reliability.
The B-DER project will develop a platform to enable peer-to-peer energy transactions between DER, allowing households, with energy generation capabilities, to trade energy in a distributed, optimal, verifiable and transparent fashion. To achieve this mission, the project partners will develop a novel optimization algorithm that allows households to minimize their electricity cost and maximize the use of locally generated PV energy while at the same time respecting the LV-grid constraints and losses.
To enable secure and verifiable decentralized energy transactions between the involved agents, the project will implement the optimization algorithm on a blockchain-smart contract architecture. The project assesses the technical and economic potential of the developed platform using actual data of households’ demand and PV generation profiles, as well as EV charging stations demand in a residential neighborhood in Amsterdam. The socio-economic and regulatory issues of peer to peer and community based markets will also be studied in this project.

projects.title: PARENT Project: PARticipatory platform for sustainable ENergy managemenT
projects.description:
The PARENT project (JPI Urban Europe) aims to increase engagement of individuals in the responsible management of their own electricity usage. It develops an innovative technical platform for participatory energy management, fuelled by novel analytics, visualisation and gamification techniques. Using energy monitors, electricity consumption and solar Photovoltaics energy production data in households is collected and analyzed, and information, tips and feedback are provided to each individual household using mobile and web applications. The PARENT project operates across three European cities: Amsterdam (Netherlands), Bergen (Norway) and Brussels (Belgium). 
In Amsterdam, the "Borneo-Eiland Prosumers Community" pilot installation aims to allow prosumers to have better insight of their electricity consumption and solar energy production, get personalized tips, engage with neighbors to reduce interaction with the electricity grid, and build an energy independent community. The pilot was launched in March 2017 targeting 30 households in the East of Amsterdam and is called "East Harbour Prosumers Community". The pilot is lead and executed by Utrecht University and Resourcefully. For more information about the project and pilot, please visit: https://goo.gl/gUkjQq , or check out this video interview: https://youtu.be/-KzjCnrfk5s

profile_positions.description: Since 2022 I am serving as an Associate Editor for IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid and IEEE Power Engineering Letters.
profile_positions.title: Associate Editor

profile_positions.description:
4TU.NIRICT is the Netherlands Institute for Research on ICT and comprises all ICT research of all technical universities in the Netherlands (4TU). Since 2022 I am a member of the 4TU.NIRICT management team.
For more info: https://www.4tu.nl/nirict/
profile_positions.title: Member of the Management Board

profile_positions.description:
Project HighLO (High Energy Physics Tools in Limit Order Book Analysis) uses advanced data analytics and AI methods from particle physics to better understand trading behavior in commodity and financial markets and detect market manipulations. My role is to lead the electricity markets research in this collaborative project between Wageningen University and CERN.

Project webpage: https://www.highlo.org/
profile_positions.title: Lead electricity markets research - Project HighLO
